Definition: Classify the given comment whether it conveys anything impolite, offensive, or mockingly abusive by providing "insult" or "non-insult".

Positive Examples.input: Comment: No wonder Hillary got beat by a circus clown.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is insult because it is scornful and disrespectful.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: I guess when you're clueless you stick your head into every hole.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is non-insult because it does not disrespect any group.

Negative Examples.input:
Comment: Hillary Clinton was not my girlfriend.

I did not have sexual relations with that woman.
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment might be obscene but not insult.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: She is weak and useless, time to run her off
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment is insult because it is disrespectful.

Comment: In the marine safety world, what a vessel should have aboard, especially for a voyage like this, is an EPIRB - Emergency Position Indicating Radio Beacon - that sends one's coordinates to SAR resources upon being manually or automatically (hydrostatic release) activated, and is registered to the ship so they know exactly what they're looking for and where.

Satellite phone is a nice extra, as is a SPOT device that even most non-mariners are aware of.

That they missed acquiring such basic survival gear makes you wonder what kind of "veteran sailors" they consulted before casting off.

The headline for this story should read "Idiots lucky to be alive; lost at sea 5 months for no good reason"

Comment: The objection to current 'no-kill' programs is that all they do once implemented is allow animal shelters to withhold the very services for which taxpayers fund animal shelters!

Hence the desperation of that poor guy and his cat in Juneau.  Cat had cancer.  He didn't want it to suffer anymore.  The shelter refused to euthanize it and  the man didn't have money to pay a vet to do so.

These 'no-kill' idiots boast that thanks to their worthless policies shelter intake and euthanasia numbers are down.  This is a meaningless, tautological argument.  They're essentially bragging that 'fewer animals are being taken in and euthanized in shelters' because shelters have stopped taking in and euthanizing animals!

Where do those animals go?  Beneath wheels of cars, in predators' jaws, into the weeds to waste away from untreated diseases, or out into winter snow to freeze and starve to death.

It's a 'shell-game' allowing weak people to hide their eyes from the deaths of the 'pets' they abandon.

Comment: The recovery had almost nothing to do with Reagan and almost everything to do with Fed chairman Paul Volcker's easing of short-term interest rates, which had been set high to end the stagflation that plagued the Clinton presidency. The deficit spending for tax relief has never been shown then or now to have had any measureable stimulative effect. It was a giveaway to rich people. Once again, we have a consumer economy. Corporations don't expand business unless they have an expanding market, and putting money in the hands of consumers works, because they will spend it all. The rich buy stock and portfolios and keep that money. Reagan was a pretty but dumb actor. As we have seen, a lot of Americans love pretty but dumb actors.

I don't see any revisionism in Krugman. He apologized for that overreaction. Those who follow Krugman understand the circumstances and are OK with him. Those who have always hated Krugman and other brainy economists continue to loathe him, so nothing changes.

Comment: You can read into this story that the "end is nigh" and get the impression that it's the all leading up to a climate-change apocalypse.  Not so.  

"...this year the second worst in recorded history in terms of land lost."  So, when did they start keeping records of "land lost"?  I'd guess about 1950s. The headline says it: that's about 60 years ago. 1958, to be exact, when almost TWICE as much area was reduced to char and ash.  Decades before anybody read, thought or talked about something called "climate change."  Let's call it "nature change", because she does change. All the time. 

You think that a couple of hundred fires throughout B.C. is significant?  Nah.  One long, hot summer, there were THOUSANDS of fires--most never brought under control--throughout northwest U.S. and B.C.  Way back in 1910.  Look it up.  That's a long time before mankind started have any real effect on what we now call "climate change."

One thing has changed: a lot more people live in or near the woods.

Comment: My guess is that if Mr. Hodginkson wasn't directing his anger at the president and the Republican party, he'd have been directing it somewhere else. People with the kind of internal turmoil that spills over into homicidal rage have issues that go well beyond the state of political discourse.

Still, I have no doubt the current climate of animosity and uncivil rhetoric exacerbates this kind of thing. And, in all honesty, that's my biggest problem with the current administration. Most presidents let their emotions get the better of them at weak moments, but we've never before (at least in my lifetime, going back to Eisenhower) had a president whose default mode was one of incivility and verbal attack toward those with whom he disagrees. It is a big concern.

All sides of the political conversation need to ratchet it down. No question of it. But if that doesn't get modeled at the top level of government, is anything likely to change?

Comment: Actually Jim, the primitive Church in Rome used Greek. And when they switched to Latin, they had a choice between two Latins--(1) classical Latin, which was still very much alive as a high brow language studied in rhetoric, and (2) vernacular Latin, "vulgar" Latin, the language of every day conversation.

They choose vulgar Latin, and it is that form of Latin that was preserved in the Latin liturgy. 

I just amazes me that this simple fact--that Latin replacing Greek was a choice in favour of the vernacular--doesn't come up in this discussions of Latin versus vernacular.

Comment: Now, in Quebec, mining companies who wish to develop new mines must submit to an environmental review, submit detailed plans and place the money in escrow with the province to refurbish the site following eventual closure. Along with that they are subject to stringent ongoing inspections throughout the life of the mine. New projects do not get the green light until the money is there and the plan approved. This has delayed a number of pending projects - and that is a good thing. It does nothing, of course, to rehabilitate old abandoned mine sites, or reverse the polluted lakes and rivers (Chibougamau is a prime example), but at least Quebec is on the right track. Their rules are currently the most stringent in Canada.

Comment: The study above does NOT say that every record breaking weather condition is caused by man. They are looking at the percentage of such events in which manmade conditions play a part. And how does that compare to other explanations including man for extreme change in weather?" Here is a good way to look at it from some charts with real data look at it as a question and not a conclusion if you like, then try to find an explanation that works better.   https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2015-whats-warming-the-world/

Comment: If that is truly your thoughts, then you might be missing the point of subsistence hunting. By way of example, people bowhunt to get some extra time in as it extends their season, and because it adds an extra challenge. It's sport hunting, from certain perspectives. What Chris and his people do isn't sport. It's not designed to level a playing field or add unnecessary challenges to make it more interesting. It's not even about the methods used during the origins of the tradition. It's about putting food on the tables of their community using whatever tools they have at their disposal. The tradition isn't in the tools they use; the tradition is in the act of going out into the frigid seas to bring home a whale and feed them for the winter. Based on that, the spirit of their tradition looks quite intact to me.

Comment: No, but they are a pre-requisite.  I own and manage a software development company, something you can't easily do if you've never programmed yourself. Comment: Your "facts" are wrong. Under the legislation DOC had to work with at the time-under two different Administrations, made it a law that any new construction or expansion  had to be financed by local communities. The decision to build the large prison was made by the previous administration based on the fact that the Mat-Su Borough was the only one that stepped up- unfortunately none of the rural communities did. There were never funds available for needed expansion in Bethel or Nome. The desire was to get prisoners out of the Private prisons in AZ and Colorado. That was accomplished. One might argue that we should have left them there- or refused to build the prison unless it was located in South Palmer- but not that there was a pot of money for rural expansion that had been redirected somehow to Goose Creek. I find it ironic now that folks who wanted to bring the AK prisoners home and get them out of dysfunctional private prisons now attack the folks that accomplished that.

Comment: The buggy whip factory died because there was not enough demand for buggy whips with the advent of the internal combustion engine. The innovation came along, it was used to make better transportation, and thus the workplace, workforce and labor market evolved.

The correlation to the energy industry is, well, there is none. As long as coal is being used to produce energy, people will be hired to extract it. What the letter writer is proposing is elimination of that industry by mandate, which is not even close to what happened to buggy whips. Not that anything is stopping coal miners from choosing other lines of work now. When and if it becomes more cost effective to produce energy by other means, an evolution may occur.

It won’t happen simply because Mr. Sorenson and fellow travelers wish real hard.

Comment: "She . . . said she could never join a church that discriminates against women."

It is unfortunate that this error continues to be perpetuated, both in and out of the SDA Church.  To equate role difference with discrimination is disingenuous, at least the way the term "discrimination" is used.  Discrimination is not always bad.  We all discriminate in one way or another.  We evaluate our kids' friends, sometimes forbidding them to associate with those who exert a bad influence.  We discriminate by evaluating our friends of the opposite sex, and eventually choose one for a spouse.  In the US, we discriminate by not allowing anyone who was not born here to become president. 

Even the Godhead has role distinctions.  But these differences in roles have nothing to do with inferiority, ability, or any other negative aspect.  As long as we phrase it as "discrimination," we can't even have a meaningful discussion.

Comment: Commuting by bicycle is fine if you have access to dedicated bike lanes. If you need to travel on the roads with heavy trucks and buses, I would recommend getting a motorcycle instead of a bike for commuting. Motorcycle riders wear the best helmets, often including face guards, and high quality protective outer wear. For exercise, learn how to repair your motorbike and enjoy the marvellous engineering of your motorbike! 

Government regulators should impose motorcycle safety requirements on (non motorized) cyclists for bicycles on the road. A vintage Bianchi bike on a bike path without a helmet, no problem. When on a public roadway with all its dangers, regulations should impose motorcycle grade helmets, large motorcycle grade electric lights, licensing, road safety exams etc.....Cycling advocates put safety first!

Comment: Those teachers who apply and earn their NBCT are not the ones who are likely to leave the profession, they are committed teachers.  Paying them more bonuses will not likely have an effect on whether or not they will stay.  
The DOE must first attract and then support new teachers.   Higher starting pay to draw the bright to teaching,  a pay scale that rewards teachers to stay in the profession, and support for those beginning teachers in the form of mentoring and/or cohort support groups would go a long way in attracting and retaining teachers.
I highly doubt those considering teaching,  just entering the profession, or contemplating leaving the profession, think to themselves "Hey, I wish the NBCT bonus was higher!" 
Lastly, the DOE needs to create more "pre-teacher" academies in those areas hard to staff.  Where those who live in those areas consider teaching in those hard to staff locations.
Congratulation on earning your NBCT!

Comment: A joke isn't a good joke if you end up having to explain it, I suppose.

The punishment of tying a person to a wooden toilet and dragging him/her through the village was common place in the 14th century. It wasn't a figment of my imagination, it was historical fact. Comment: @Rick... The point you are missing is that all living beings will suffer and die. If you fundamentaly understand how the food-chain works, you will realize that there is a predator and a prey. We happen to be on top or share the top. There will always be death and suffering. When one species within the food chain stops killing (plants or animals) they become extinct. If I stopped killing bear, moose, deer, etc... to eat and started only eating plant matter, i am effectively eliminating a food source for another species. There is a finite supply of all matter on this earth. I hunt, trap, and fish. Above all, I am a conservationist. I believe if we effectively manage the species on this earth, there will be a supply of plants and animals for everyone today and tomorrow. When you are out berry picking this summer/fall, think about the bear that will go hungry because you ate his food source.

Comment: To correct & clarify some things said in comments on the article previous to this one, and comment on some statements in this article...

A comment on the previous article stated "The County position has not changed in over 2 weeks. During each mediation meeting, they simply listen to a new offer by the Union, then go into their own meeting for 8 hours, then come out and simply say, "no"."

That is simply not true. The Co. increased their offer more than once - several times - over the months. Most telling - just last week the Co. increased their offer by ~$3 million. The union rejected it & went on strike. Three days into the strike, the union came groveling back saying they'd accept the +$3M. The Co. said "no" - the offer is off the table, the union rejected it, demeaned the Co., & damaged the community by striking. The Co. held firm - good, IMO.

Also, the union has NOT "moved significantly closer to the county" The Co. has moved more than the union.

Prediction: strike ends Monday.

Comment: Whole lotta' armchair QBing here. Might I suggest this isn't as easy on the ground. 

That being said, here is what I see. Many clearly identifiable cops yelling at a man to drop a gun. It looks to me like he had one, but for the sake of argument, let's say he was holding the Good Book after coming from Sunday sermon. The cops still thought it was a gun, he didn't drop it, and was angling to flank the cops who were in a covered position. I wouldn't have liked it, but I would have shot him too. The screaming lady isn't helping. You can't negotiate with a cop who thinks he might be shot.

Of course they restrained him and secured the scene prior to rendering aid. This isn't the movies. Getting shot doesn't mean he is out of the fight. I've seen folks take 7.62 and multiple 5.53 rounds and keep coming. Standard proceedure is to reduce the threat, secure the scene, and call for help before rendering aid.

Maybe a tragic misunderstanding, but like it or not, this is how this has to work.

Comment: Cyclists do not have to dismount to cross at pedestrian crosswalks. it's interesting because the muni has a random blanket "rider safety"  page on their webpage that says cyclists should dismount. When I have asked APD they say cyclists can ride. Nothing in the muni code prevents cyclists from riding across sidewalks. There are so many different ideas that people have about riding or walking that are only backed up by "it's what my Mom told me" it is a little ridiculous. The big thing APD has stressed to me ( I ask every cop I meet because I like to play by the rules) is that cyclist can use sidewalks or the road but must then abide by the rules that govern pedestrians if on sidewalk OR rules governing cars if on roads. They cannot switch back and forth, I think this is a reasonable approach and something I see cyclists do daily, personally I find it dangerous. However when I am on a sidewalk or bike path that ends and spits me onto a road, I have no choice. Cops said that is fine.

Comment: 8 USC Section 1325 

(a) Improper time or place; avoidance of examination or inspection; misrepresentation and concealment of facts 

Any alien who (1) enters or attempts to enter the United States at any time or place other than as designated by immigration officers, or (2) eludes examination or inspection by immigration officers, or (3) attempts to enter or obtains entry to the United States by a willfully false or misleading representation or the willful concealment of a material fact, shall, for the first commission of any such offense, be fined under title 18 or imprisoned not more than 6 months, or both, and, for a subsequent commission of any such offense, be fined under title 18, or imprisoned not more than 2 years, or both.

Comment: "he was also content to exploit Chinese Labour to build the CPR."

Exploit is such an interesting word.  It's often regarded negatively; used often instead of coercion, which means something else entirely. In the business context, it's quite acceptable.  It's true! Retailers exploit the public's desire for low prices. 

There were two reasons why CPR's American contractor Andrew Onderdonk (not PM McDonald) hired Chinese :  He couldn't hire enough whites.  2. It was a business decision. "By 1881 Onderdonk was short of ...money. He solved his problems by hiring Chinese men at low wages. They were paid just a dollar a day, less than half the rate paid to European workers." (Source: Horizons, Canada's Emerging Identity.) He exploited Chinese who wished to leave China and work (Thanks, Mr. Onderdonk!)

They weren't coerced into coming. Work done, just over 1,000 returned to China. 14,000 chose to STAY. Life was tough; but obviously, most felt Canada STILL offered a better future than China.

Comment: Part 2

or 2) that the Son was 'homoios' "like the Father" or 
3) that the Son was "homoousios" "of the same substance with the Father".
The Council Fathers accepted the third alternative.  In the Nicene Creed, it is translated as 'being Consubstantial with the Father.'

But neither did this statement cause Arianism to go away.  Many bishops did not care for the non-biblical term to describe God [the Father], and many had reservations about what went on at Nicaea.   This issue caused much debate [among the bishops] about the nature of and place of the Son and the Holy Spirit in the divinity concept throughout most of the fourth century.  Another Byzantine emperor, Theodosius called another Ecumenical Council to take place at Constantinople [381].  It reaffirmed the Nicene teaching and added the importance of the place of the Holy Spirit.

In addition, real estate/construction in some provinces has exploded to comprise a far larger % of GDP than the past. Buying/selling desirable land is the biggest engine in Canada's economy. Comment: Before blowing off about obstruction of justice, why don't you take a moment to see what the law actually says?

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Obstruction_of_justice

To obstruct justice means to take concrete steps to impede an investigation; to destroy, conceal or remove evidence; to bribe witnesses or judges; or to lie under oath. (Perjury.)

To do nothing more than simply ask a law official to "let it go" is not obstruction. For instance, when you lean over from the passenger seat and ask a cop to let your buddy off a speeding ticket, you are not obstructing justice. You've made an inappropriate request, nothing more.

Comment: Some more concepts:

A hurricane starts where there is a column of heated, moist air.  As the heated air rises, air has to be sucked in at the bottom to take its place.  The heated column of air functions just like a chimney.

It can only form where there is very little lateral (i.e., horizontal) shear in the wind column.  That is, hurricanes originate where the air in the center of the column is originally very nearly still, e.g., in the calm air in the doldrums.  If there is a strong wind constantly blowing the top off the heated air, a hurricane won't form.
.
Once the chimney is established, why does the air swirl in a helix?

This is not the right place for an explanation of conservation of angular momentum and coriolis force.  The gist of it is that it swirls for the same reason that water in a toilet bowl swirls.  The wind speed is highest near the core for the same reason that a figure skater spins faster when they hold their arms closest to their body.

Comment: A 2011 report by the EPA seems to counter what you say.  
https://www.epa.gov/sites/production/files/2015-10/documents/2011_fluoride_questionsanswers.pdf
In question 20 they state that the optimum fluoridated levels for prevention of tooth decay is between 0.7 and 1.2 mg/L.  ANC uses the low end of that.
Also, note that the EPA's mission is different from the CDC - and they EXPLICITLY deal with that in answer #4.  That's why you get your conclusion of the EPA seems "to allow" fluoridation rather than actively support it.  The EPA cannot promote that addition of ANY substance to pure water as per their overall mandate.  In short, the EPA's overall purpose is to set maximal acceptable values on what CAN be our water (air, food, etc.)  The CDC/HHS has a much different and more proactive mandate about public health.
Put simpler still: 
EPA = limits on bad things for us, 
CDC = EPA + what can we do/add that is GOOD for us?  (Thus vaccinations, etc....)

Comment: There are some inaccuracies here that I'd like to clear up. 1. The route has not yet been permitted. The USFS and the Telluride Mountain Club are working closely together to do so. 2. The route was not established "under the cover of darkness" to hide an "illegal masterpiece". It was established by rock climbers in the same spirit that every other rock climb in America has been established. A climber has a vision of a route that he/she thinks would be worthy and installs it to the best of their ability. Noone at that time envisioned the popularity of the route. We are now working backwards to permit this thing and are happy the USFS are interested in that as well. 3. Rockfall is the biggest hazard up there, wear a helmet. 

An engineering report and study are almost complete and we will begin working with the USFS engineers this winter in hopes of a clear path towards permitting next season. For more info checkout telluridemountainclub.org
Thanks
Josh Borof 
Telluride Mountain Club

Comment: As a child growing up in eastern Canada, I distinctly remember my father talking about how important the Combines Investigation Act was for Canadian enterprise. At that time, when the multinationals' share of foodstuffs was perhaps even higher than it is today, there were rules and regulations governing origin of product labelling, and more importantly the amount of eye level display the cartel could monopolize. My children have all grown up with this lesson in mind, and because the labelling requirements seem less stringent today, they do their own research. Buying local creates employment in our communities and wastes less energy in transporting products to market. A pretty simple concept, that we all can follow simply by taking the time. 

It's our own way of pushing back against anti-Canadian trade sanctions by our neighbour to the south.

Comment: Naval aircraft do not have "registration" numbers.
They have BUNO's. 
BUNO is the abbreviation for "Bureau Number", a holdover from when the numbers for Naval aircraft were assigned by the Bureau of Aeronautics.

BUNO's were first known as "serial numbers", then "building numbers" and later termed "designating numbers". 

A BUNO is assigned to an aircraft when it is initially ordered, not when it is actually delivered to the Navy.

History lesson for the day.
A good reporter should investigate before reporting.

Comment: The Feds, each individual State, the different levels of government-even in Oregon, what is being purchased (goods, intangibles, personal services,) how much the maximum purchase will be, whether it is being funded by Federal or State tax money, whether it is being funded by a grant--whether that Grant is Federal, State or private.

 All sorts of things get involved in government procurement!

Spending a "Bill and Melinda Gates"  Grant is light-years different than spending a Federal pass-thru Grant from the University of  Washington on to an Oregon non-profit contract or sub-grant (there is a difference there, too!) funneled through the Oregon Alcohol and Drug Abuse Program and then through the Lane County bureaucracy!

Comment: Mr.  Dickson's arguments about the political economy of global warming are almost 100% specious. The USA may only have 4.5% of the world's population and 6% of the global land area, but the US economy is the largest on earth and we produced, over the last 100 years, most of the anthropogenic CO2 now warming the atmosphere.  The USA occupies a leadership position on this issue because we are responsible for creating it, in  very large part.

If we were to really show some leadership, China and India would follow. The argument that the USA lacks influence is utterly specious. Fact is, China is already leading in solar panel production and deployment, and the USA lags much of the developed world in adaptation and alternative energy application.

This option is available only on the top of the line, and I have been driving on dirt roads and some very bumpy paved roads here in the Laurentians. Certainly the Alfa will be a very welcome option in the high end market, the owners will have something unique to show off, but it will be important to have service facilities comparable to the three German companies plus Volvo and Land Rover. The article did not describe the cockpit controls and layout, which are a major differential in to-day's market. On that point, the 2018 Audi Q5 is hard to beat.

Comment: I've owned a Countryman for 5 years. Get the base engine model. The "S" and higher models have a problematic turbo that has all sorts of well known issues. Acceleration from stop is slow, but when the rpms are up, response is quick. You will have no issues passing other cars. Reliability has been rock solid, nothing but routine maintenance.  The rear hatch has a false floor that can be removed. I have no issues transporting 3 suitcases with the floor removed. You will love the fuel economy, I routinely drive one way to NYC on $60-$70 gas using cruise control and eco mode. The car handles like a sports car, the seats are super comfy and the interior is very quiet. The car even after 5 years feels tightly screwed together. The only thing I don't like are the run flat tires, you can feel the pot holes.

That being said, I disagree that wilderness is a rare experience in Colorado. Comment: Almost every time a species gets listed as threatened or endangered, the developers go nuts, and groups like pacific legal foundation disparage the species or subspecies as insignificant.   In this case, they seem to be basing their argument on the fact that the Prebles Jumping Mouse is a subspecies as opposed to a full species. However the endangered species act protects critters that are endangered, even under these facts.
In situations where a landowner wants to develop in the critters habitat, the endangered species act provides that permits can be issued to allow for the development, but certain hoops need to be jumped though, no pun intended.
As a society we have made the decision not to allow plants and animals to go extinct if at all possible.  We can either keep that promise to future generations or not.  Yes, it can be costly or inconvenient, but most Americans have been supportive of these protections.

Comment: Actually, I do believe the plan includes provision for either/or, or both the 'Sikorsky CH-148 Cyclone', or 'Bell CH-146 Griffon' helicopters.

The problem with using helos to hunt submarines, is that the subs can hear them coming. Instead of this reliance, we should have a 'net' of sonar buoys and hydrophones that can keep an ear out; and if something is detected, illuminated with sonar and tracked and targeted; perhaps it's not a plane or a ship or even another sub that fires the torpedo -- What if squads of soldiers on the ice, crewing a hole, could slip in a torpedo and attack the intruder?

My point is: It's not necessary to have a submarine, to fire a torpedo. Already, air-dropped torpedoes are common, as are ship borne torpedoes that fire off the deck.

What if Canadians could fire our torpedoes from small (inexpensive, which means we can buy in numbers) ships, or even from (rather large) snow mobiles on top of the winter ice?

I'd gladly pay twice as much to avoid paying AW a nickel.

"92% of BC Hydro's power generation is hydroelectric", oh, so that is why they call it BC Hydro. -)

BC Hydro Burrard Thermal 960 MW Generating station is a standby unit, only used when there is a disruption in power transmission, or in low flow years when the hydro reservoirs run low on water. Years ago, in Montana, the local Air Force Base paid in cash.  There were unhappy towns people because of the problems young servicemen tend to bring to towns.

Think outside the Eugene Property Tax Box, guys!

Comment: Your motor is the same as in all typical Toyotas:  Camry and Sienna minivan.  The Toyota V6 is also installed in the Lotus Evora.

The Lotus Evora is more heavily tuned, and expected to rev 5000-7000rpm on a regular basis----if you want full power, then use 91 octane.  

My sister owns a Sienna, and my business colleague owns an ES also.  With an automatic transmission, I don't think either vehicle has ever seen 6000rpm in its life.  The fuel should match your driving style, not the vehicle.  Using mid-grade twice, then premium once, has no logic or basis in science.

There is nothing wrong with fuel from a discount place like Superstore.  In western canada, there is only one refinery, so the only difference between gas stations is the additive package specific to each make.

Unless you are a performance driver, 87 octane is more than adequate for most use.  Octane is "resistance to knock".  Engines only knock when under load (acceleration or mountain driving, esp in heat) at high RPM

Comment: "...come up with a solution that won't tank the entire economy for the next two decades. "

It's too late to avoid tanking the economy - at least for BC. Shortly after the turn of the century (i.e. not that long ago!), real estate and construction comprised ~15% of BC's GDP. It is now ~40%. Some ways to address this issue will be better than others, but it is absolutely clear the economy is going to have to "take its medicine" on this one to a big degree.

So we either stay the course, keeping our economic focus on facilitating citizenship of convenience and enriching those born early enough to really gain from this price run-up, all while steadily alienating larger and larger groups of younger people (who we ultimately expect to form our tax base and provide essential services). Or we rethink the policy fixations from multiple levels of government that see ever-increasing real estate prices as sacrosanct.

Comment: Thanks UC! We're glad you're here!  :)

The character limit is approximately two paragraphs long, but you're correct, there is no limit on the number of posts. We did originally have a longer character limit on comments, but received a lot of negative feedback during testing. We've found that posting a two-paragraph comment, then posting additional paragraphs as replies to that comment, has been a decent compromise, as the comments stay in order within the replies, and it gives others a chance to get a word in edgewise. Comment: lol! Yeah, there are some truly ridiculous degrees out there. My parents didn't help me whatsoever, but I knew I had to get a college education because I wanted to do better than my lower-middle class parents. I took a year of community college (free w/Pell Grants because we were po'), then joined the military for 4 years to get the GI Bill and took classes here and there while still in the military, then got out and finished my degree at a public university full time for about 2.5 years. But that was the '90s and college was cheaper. 

I struggled in my 20s and early 30s to figure things out and work my way up, but I know I wouldn't be bringing home 6 figures today without my college degree. We're saving for our kids' college and have them in tutoring to keep them ahead of their peers. But I still don't know if we'll have enough to cover 100% of their tuition. By then (in 9 years), we may still need to pitch in to help them. But my opinion is that a degree is a necessity these days.

Comment: We didn't have a say in the voting process, your statement is quite false and misleading.  

There was an open call for nominations and an independent advisory council was selected to choose out of those submitted.  Canadians were able to submit a formal opinion survey on the long list, twelve nominations who were chosen by the council, to gauge their decisions.  The advisory council also submitted a short list of five nominees and did focus group testing of those five to see what the reaction would be.  This short list of five choices was then submitted  to the Governor of the Bank of Canada and the Minister of Finance.  The Minster made the final choice.  

Nowhere did we vote for anyone on the bill.  We were given the ability to submit an opinion survey on twelve nominees already chosen, not of the entire list.  Granted, submissions were originally taken publicly, but we did not get to vote on the list.

http://www.bankofcanada.ca/banknotes/banknoteable/selection-process/

Comment: You sound convinced of your conspiracy theory that a de-emphasis on the hierarchy and conformity was a V2 ploy. Maybe the following explanation will help you understand the need for this.

One of the movements was to recover an understanding of Church founded on biblical and patristic sources. These sources provided an understanding of the early Church as a communion of local Churches, with the bishop as the focus of unity, sharing a common faith but with a certain diversity of practice in a society that was largely pagan. Discovery of documents from the early patristic period in the late 19th-C contributed to a renewed understanding of the episcopate necessitating a re-evaluation of the relationship between bishops and in particular the bishop of Rome. It meant that the pyramidal model employed since the Constantinian era was no longer an authentic representation, a flatter model with more equivalence between local churches was opted for with renewed emphasis on scripture (paraphrase)

Comment: It's good that the article brings certain issues to light, but its weakness is that it looks at 'community benefit' spending as almost solely a matter of charity care.  I would agree that a hospital absorbing the difference between a billed charge and the amount paid toward that bill by an insurer (public or private) should not count as community benefit spending.   But there are many other salutory, measurable, bona fide ways besides charity carethat hospitals can invest in community health.  Many of them attend to the growing evidence that social determinants of health are crucial.  For example, investments in affordable senior housing, early childhood enrichment, targeted group outreach and special services, nutrition for those living in or near poverty, transportation not only for health care appointments but also for social capital -- these are evidence-based ways to promote health and provide community benefit.  Such worthy investments are much needed and deserve recognition.

Comment: Where are merit and ability in all this ostensibly praiseworthy diversity? And quite apart from merit, do we have enough positions in even the largest of our universities and corporations to represent all the non-male, non-white human beings in Canada? Can inclusiveness include everyone this side of the grave? Where will the diverseness of the diversity end? Or perhaps it will have no end ....

Remember those lamentable Depression-era signs, "No Irish need apply"? Ms Wente is right: through the best of good intentions, we are circling right back into some of the worst abuses of the past. There were many talented and ingenious Irish who were denied work in the 1930s, simply because they were Irish. In our zeal to be "fair" today, let's not forget their counterparts of today.  Otherwise the collective "outcome" for Canada may not be what we might have hoped for. Keep merit firmly in the mix, otherwise through "goodness" we risk sliding into absurdity.

Europeans on the other hand had wheat- one of the most energy rich food sources in the world. They were building grain stores, because they could actually in 3 months of labour provide enough food for the village for a year - leaving 9 months to spend on other pursuits beyond finding food.
Finally - Europe is laid out East-West in roughly the same set of latitudes. This is important - it means all of Europe has fairly similar climates. Comment: Very insightful. I know, basically, my family history - Swedish from Dad's side, Irish, Welsh and Native American from Mom's. Although the old folks would deny it and we know the family history back to 1810 (on Mom's side), it wouldn't surprise me if there's some black because of the curly hair, but that could just as easily be from the Irish. DNA results wouldn't really change who I am. I was raised to respect all of the cultures that my parents brought to the table. Candy in our shoes for St. Lucia's Day, lots of foods from the European side of the family. Our bedtime stories were about the world on the turtle's back. Mom used to terrify me on Halloween with wendigo (not from Mom's tribe, actually). The fact still remains that we're all about 10 generations removed from each other ... at the most. DNA shouldn't change who we are because ultimately we are the sum total of who we were raised to be, not who slept with who centuries ago.

  However (and it's a big however), if you INTENTIONALLY break that window, you have committed a crime; a far different and more serious act than accidentally breaking a window.  Intent impacts the judgment of acts in a legal sense and, IMO, it should impact our judging the morality or immorality of an act.  Ms Shurtz's "blackface" was a foolish act....it was not a malicious act.  IMO, it was NOT illegal, and it was NOT immoral.

Gary Crum

Comment: Dr. Kozak, your desire to improve pedestrian safety in Honolulu is laudable.  Responsibility for pedestrian safety starts first with drivers, who need to slow down, consciously look for pedestrians, obey the laws and quit rushing.  Second, pedestrians need to be alert, not distracted, and look to make eye contact with nearby drivers of cars.  Banning the use of cellphones while crossing city and state streets would certainly help.  As for intersection design, that is more of a science than an art.  Both the cities and state follow the Uniform Manual on Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD), a federal guideline which specifies when certain treatments (such as no turning movements and Barnes Dances) should be used.  Research on Barnes Dances shows they work incredibly well in some locations and horribly in others.  Cities have removed Barnes Dances where the impact on traffic congestion was severe and unjustified by pedestrian counts.   I urge the city to continue its safe pedestrian movement.

Comment: In none of the countries who beat us in health care - none - is it illegal to offer private insurance. Not one. 
Nevertheless the columnist still manages to slip in his own illogical bias against private health care. Sure, we're #1 in administration. Because we have to be. When you're waiting 2 years for a joint replacement everything has to be in place when you actually get there, so blood tests, imaging, preoperative assessments, anaesthesia consultations all have to be spot on when the day actually comes. And when it comes, guess what? Our care is as good as anywhere in the world. But to jump from that to the blithe statement that these achievements are due to our wonderful one-payer system is nonsense.  And is it any surprise that our seniors have above average numbers of chronic illnesses at any one time? They are all on waiting lists, from joint replacements to kidney transplants to cataract surgery to assessments for diabetic care. They are diagnosed - then the waiting begins.

Comment: The problem with Feldman's quote is that it's meaningless from a public policy perspective, and as a lobbyist he knows it. When you are trying to achieve a goal you have access to multiple levers. A good person with a gun will not cause harm. A bad person with a less effective weapon is limited in the damage they can cause. A bad person with the best weapon but no one to use it on cannot cause harm. So if your goal is to reduce harm you can try to craft any of those situations.

The problem with 'looking at the type of person' is that there are 323 million people in the US. For absolutely anything illegal (e.g. drugs) you can find a large minority of people who could handle it responsibly. The statement '[Blank] doesn't [blank], people [blank].' applies to absolutely everything. But in all other things we recognize that public policy cannot be tuned to an individual level. If you want to reduce speeding you do not 'look at the type of person prone to speeding,' you install speed bumps.

Comment: You also have to be aware that "money in the bank" could take weeks. In cases where cashing cheques, it isn't cleared until issuing bank signs off on the transaction. It is possible for your branch to clear payment and release funds to your account only later to revert it when issuing bank flags the fraud.

The best way to exchange funds is certified check; then take that check to the branch that issued it to verify and cash it prior to completing transaction.

Comment: Distracted driving is not just about teens and texting. Fleet vehicles/company cars are also a real issue. Employees who are "on the clock" often feel a need to multi-task and use their drive time to make phone calls, read emails and return texts. All major distractions that lead to accidents. 
For individuals there are apps that can block the use of your phone, ones like AT&T DriveMode which is FREE. For companies there is a need for accountability, tracking and enforcing cell phone bans. There are programs like FleetMode to do that.
One area often overlooked is all the vehicles that Colorado has in its fleet. Cars for inspectors, regulators and agriculture department. Should they not have anti-distraction technology? I would love to see Colorado lead by example and not just tell us not to use our phones but have their employees not using them also.

Comment: I understand your feelings re many comments in these forums and agree with you about Obama, but the commennts don't  prove we're "a nation of right-wing trolls".  Total popular support for the centre-left (Liberals, NDP, Green) is consistently over 60 per cent in the vast majority of Canadian elections. Looking back over the last 20+ years , for example, the total popular support for Conservative parties has been:  31.9% (2015), 39.6 % (2011), 37.7% (2008), 36.3 % (2006), 29.6 (2004), 37.7 % (2000, Reform + Progressive Conservative), 38.2 (1997, Reform +PC), 33.7% (1993, Reform + PC).  Before 1900, the Conservative Party had some claim to being the natural governing party in Canada, but not since, despite Stephen Harper's efforts to return to such (for them) halcyon days. Source: http://www.lop.parl.gc.ca/ParlInfo/compilations/ElectionsAndRidings/ResultsParty.aspx.  Still, centre-left voters cannot be complacent and must continue voicing support for progressive policies in dark times.

Comment: 'bavius', see my above post for actual facts; real wages *HAVE* increased quite substantially in the past 25 years.

The myth of stagnate wages is based off the fact that wages DECLINED in the 1980's and early 1990's, prior to NAFTA, and it took until ~2005 (depending on the measure used) to get back to the level they were in the late 1970's.

This lead to the totally incorrect assumption that, if wages in 1980 and 2005 are the same, it must be a straight-line between them and therefore wages were stagnant.  In reality 1980 and 2005 were just the top points of a 'U' shaped curve.

Again, see the above post for references that demonstrate exactly what I am talking about.

Comment: Airlines shouldn't be allowed to shrink the seat-size any more. Period. It's not only screamingly uncomfortable for anyone with long legs or a body shape that doesn't look like a pencil, it's also unsafe. On one flight the guy who boarded last, behind me (I always board toward the end, hate fighting my way to my seat), he was Samoan & must have weighed 300lbs. It wasn't muscle, sad to say. He had a look of fear in his eyes when he realized his seat was the middle one, between me & a 9 year-old girl traveling with split family seats. There was no way he was going to fit in that small seat without spilling out both sides, crowding all three of us into the narrow space between rows. And it was a full flight. So I stood up, told the man he could switch seats with me, and being the window seat he'd have a bit more room & could lean back into the window area. You could just *feel* the relief and gratitude pour out of him. I gave him the armrest, and he was even able to nap on the way home.

Comment: That's not quite correct. The US has a similar or lower overall suicide rate than many countries with very strict gun control. In every nation people will choose the most lethal method available to them with some surprisingly consistent variations by gender. If "legal access to guns" were a primary driver in suicide we would have the highest rate in the world. Indeed, though it probably isn't statistically significant, the actual percentage of US suicides using firearms has dropped from a consistent just over 50% to just under 50% in '14 / '15.  Suicide is a sociological and psychological problem, not a means problem.

A problem with studies researching suicide is the limitations of the research pool. By definition the only living subjects are those who failed in their attempts, either because they were making a "cry for help" not truly wanting to die, were unintentionally interrupted, or made a mistake in execution. The determined, well-planned suicides are unavailable for study.

Comment: You are correct indeed, but even our beloved and fairly solid major banks have the same issue - if all my fellow TD depositors ran to the bank for our money, they don't have it. Of course the normal upward sloping yield curve means the average interest rate spread is bigger than the spread at any particular number of years. Take in the shortest deposits, to get what you pay down, make the longest loans, and a very narrow concentration in one asset. Comment: I wonder if this would/should bring an end to the practice of tipping.  Australia and Norway ensure a "living wage" for all, including restaurant workers; but tipping is not practiced. Somehow I suspect they will want the best of both worlds---the Australian/Norwegian minimum wages, PLUS tips.

Comment: In my youth, part of the bonusses of working in charity, is that I got to see the world. I had been to over 50 countries on 4 different continents by the age of 26 - rarely for less than 3 months at a time. Of course, such a travel schedule means I occasionally had the misfortune of getting ill while abroad.
In the USA - it left me in agony in a hotel room from a stomach infection that would need 20 minutes of any doctor's time to fix... and no ability to get it because the bill would have bankrupted me a thousand times over. Hell medical debt was the NUMBER ONE cause of bankruptcy in America at the time, and represented over 60% of all credit card debt (this was pre-ACA).

In Brazil, I experienced the best medical care I have ever had. I was even given 2 hours of oxygen treatment purely as a preventative, immune-boosting, measure. All for a flu . I was up and about in 3 days instead of the usual 2 weeks.

Government healthcare.
Free of charge.
Even for a foreign visitor.

Best ever.

Comment: Yes, well "the state's description" is not intuitively comprehensible. "Sexual violence" does not mean, in any of the fifty states or at the federal level, what ordinary people would understand to be "violence."

No actual violence is necessary other than a person having sex with someone under fourteen or fifteen to be considered "sexually violent." The relationship could well have been completely agreeable to both parties and without any element of force or coercion but still considered, for purposes of state or federal law "sexually violent." That doesn't mean that the act should be legal but to call it "violent" does actual violence to the language and undermines the public's need to understand a crime, untainted by hyperbole and misdirection.

Comment: My 2012 Nissan leaf electric car is equipped with "vehicle sound for pedestrians".   It's a backup chime similar to the door-ajar sound on other sedans and only a slight whistle as you accelerate off the line. It only has to be loud enough to be audiable from about 10ft. you barely even hear it in the car.  I'd prefer if it wasn't there but it's still very quiet.  Electric cars in general are far far quieter than gas engines, hence the requirement for noise makers.  You never really notice how loud a gas engine is until drive a vehicle that doesn't need one.  The roads would be much quieter if everyone drove electric. Test drive one! I love sports cars but the instant torque and a vibration-free electric motor makes a pretty nice ride.

Comment: Might be a bit more persuasive with some actual data.  In 2010, medical malpractice cost about $55.6 billion a year, with all but $10 billion coming from "defensive medicine."  That seems like a lot, but comprises only 2.4% of the cost of medical care.

Even if the entire cost of medical malpractice was eliminated, the cost savings would be a tiny piece of the overall puzzle.  And that assumes you can eliminate it all.  The fact that we spend more than 4x the amount of actual damages to try to prevent suits says a lot.

Frankly, I've always doubted the "defensive medicine" argument anyway.  It's always struck me as a good excuse for billing additional (and likely unneeded) procedures and raking payment.
